reviews.text:
If you need an inexpensive place to stay for a night or two then you may consider this place but for a longer stay I'd recommend somewhere with better amenities. 

Pros:
Great location- you're right by the train station, central location to get to old town and new town, and right by sight seeing his tours. Food, bars, and shopping all within walking distance. Location, location, location.
Very clean and very good maid service

Cons:
Tiny rooms 
Uncomfortable bed 
Absolutely no amenities 
No phone in room 
No wardrobe 

Was given a lot of attitude about me and my husband sharing a room which was quite strange and we were charged 15 pounds more for double occupancy not sure why that matters I felt like it was a money grab. It was just handled in a kind of odd manner to me... 

If you book this hotel all you get is a bed, desk, and a bathroom. It isn't awful but know what you're getting into.
Had an excellent lunch here. I shared the meat board and a large tomato salad with my husband which was just enough food for us both and very refreshing. Service was quick and attentive as well.
They have an excellent breakfast here if you're a hungry traveler. Get one of the full breakfast plates. Service was really good.

Delicious! I kept hearing to try a bagel while in Montreal and I'm glad I did! Wow, it was delightful. I had a regular bagel with cream cheese, it was plain cream cheese but there was something magical about it. Also, the chai tea was good. My fiancé had the breakfast bagel which was also tasty.

I stopped in here and bought some books for the train for one pound each and a lovely scarf. My husband was lucky enough to score a designer jacket in his size. The store is very clean and organized although a bit tight.
Nice little spot for a coffee. Not far from other stuff as well and close to the Hotel Motel One.

This is a cute little restaurant, but it's in a spot where you wouldn't expect it to be. Very romantic and good service.  The waitress even asked if we had any dietary restrictions, allergies, or things we did not like. 

Me and my fiancé started off with the blue fin tuna appetizer with grapefruit and other delicious items. 

I had the scallops which were served with amazing slivers of pear and mushroom. They were buttery, rich and well cooked. 

My fiancé had the duck meat and heart plate. His was slightly tough but still very tasty. Very strange to say but wouldn't be shy of eating heart again. 

Dessert was a peach upside down cake with citrus sorbet. It was refreshing and a great way to end the meal.

Our waitress was awesome! No idea what her name was but she had long hair and a lot of colorful tattoos. We had the happy hour special with their house red wine which was surprisingly really tasty. We snacked on a few things and all was good, it was the perfect pick me up before a late dinner.

Amazing meal. Me and my fiancé came here for dinner and were seated in the garden/patio at a picnic table. We ended up talking to the couple next to us and sharing a few bites of items which was interesting. It's hard not to when sitting so close to someone. 

We started with the classic foie gras which was delicious, the homemade bread was the best ever.

We had some of our neighbors brussel sprouts and lamb.

Then came our beef for two, which was probably the best beef dish I've ever had. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned. 

Our waiter was great, I'm not sure of his name he was very nice and helpful since neither of us can read or speak French we were completely dependent on him. 

My complaint would be that the beef for two is WAY, WAY too much food for two people. We were obviously visitors to Montreal and I felt so bad about wasting the food. Please either do a smaller portion or warn patrons.. The beef is enough for four! 

Also if you are sitting on the patio/garden bring your shades!

The drink was decent but watery and we had to wait twenty minutes in the heat for it. They seemed disorganized bubbling around in their little spaces, running back and forth putting out about a drink every couple minutes. With every other store on the street selling the same thing we could have waited somewhere indoors with a/c for a better drink. Just no.

Very good food and service (while there). Started with the goat cheese and fig which was very good then both me and my husband had the lamb chop, and ended with the cheese plate with chutney. The only down side is when we made the reservation the lady said we only had 45 minutes to eat and they would kick us out even if we weren't done... We ended up getting to the restaurant early and it was dead (it picked up later) but we asked for any time so not sure why she needed to put us down for later and rush us... Did feel very rushed through dinner because of this so what could have been 5 stars is a 3.5 experience overall. 

You definitely need a reservation so be sure to make one. They turned quite a few people away.

tips.text: The beef for two is really for four... Order appetizers and you'll be fine
The drink was decent but watery and we had to wait twenty minutes for it... Just no.

reviews.text:
Mittlerweile gibt es in Edinburgh zwei Ableger der Motel-One-Kette - diese hier ist eher das schlechtere.

Wir hatten auf unserer Schottlandtour die Gelegenheit beide Ableger kennenzulernen, da wir beide Nächte in Edinburgh (am ersten sowie am letzten Tag) in einem der beiden Motel One's verbrachten. Von diesem hier waren wir nach dem überraschend positiven Erlebnis im Motel One an der Princes Street [1] etwas enttäuscht.

Das Hotel ist wesentlich größer und extrem unübersichtlich. Da man auf der fünften Etage noch Teile eines weiteren Gebäude, das mittels einer Glasbrücke mit dem Hauptgebäude verbunden ist, hinzugenommen hat, kann die Suche nach dem Zimmer insbesondere auf dieser Etage zu einem Gang im Labyrinth ausarten. Habe ich so noch in keinem Hotel erlebt - uns begegneten immer wieder Menschen, die sich auf der Suche nach ihren Zimmern verirrt haben.
Unser Zimmer war ähnlich aufgebaut wie das Zimmer im Motel One Princes Street - befand sich jedoch im Inneren des Gebäudes und hatte daher kein Fenster. Nur eine kleine Dachluke, die sich am oberen Ende eines etwa 3m langen Schachts befand, sorgte für einen minimalen Anteil Tageslicht im Zimmer. diese Luke ließ sich auch nicht öffnen, nur ein elektrisches Rollo ließ sich mittels eines Schalters öffnen bzw. schließen.
Sonst gilt für das Zimmer eigentlich das Gleiche wie für das Zimmer im im Motel One Princes Street: Relativ klein, trotzdem extrem ansprechend und schick gestaltet und clever durchdacht. Dazu sehr ruhig.

Im gesamten Hotel gibt es kostenloses WLAN für die Dauer des Aufenthalts für maximal 3 Geräte.

Die Lage des Motel One Royal Mile ist großartig. Vom Airlink-Flughafenbus kann man quasi in den Hoteleingang stolpern, es sind maximal 50m. Zur Royal Mile sind es etwa 100m Luftlinie (bergauf) und man benötigt etwa 5 Minuten bis dort.

Das Frühstück für 9,50 GBP / Person kann man nutzen - muss man aber nicht. Es ist eher übersichtlich und kontinetaler Prägung, trotzdem aber sehr gut. Für den gleichen Preis oder weniger bekommt man aber problemlos ein reichhaltiges Frühstück in einem der zahlreichen Cafes von Edinburgh.

Für ein oder zwei Nächte kann man hier problemlos bleiben, sollte aber nicht allzuviel erwarten. Hat man die Wahl, sollte man meiner Erfahrung nach lieber auf das andere Motel One an der Princes Street ausweichen. 


----
[1] http://www.yelp.de/biz/motel-one-edinburgh-2?hrid=7UDwl3s_DuOokkGPZXZgBw

Wahnsinn - un-fass-bar gut. Wer auf ehrliches, bodenständiges Barbecue steht, kommt hier voll auf seine Kosten.

Reekie's Smokehouse bietet Hausgemachtes aus dem Smoker. Pulled Pork, Pulled Beef und Spare Ribs - aber auch Vegetarier werden dank vegetarischem Haggis nicht verhungern.
Als Beilagen stehen die klassischen Fritten, aber auch Coleslaw, Bohnen oder eingelegte Gurken zur Wahl. Die Fritten waren dabei der Hammer. Wirklich unglaublich gut... Super dabei: es stehen verschiedene Würzungen zur Wahl, wie z.B. geräuchertes Hebridensalz, "Meat Dust" oder das Geheimrezept des Hauses. Die Portion war riesig und reicht locker für zwei.

Mein Pulled Pork Burger war perfekt. Zart, saftig, leckeres Raucharoma. Darauf Coleslaw und alles in einem selbstgemachten Brötchen.
Dazu gibt es eine Soße nach Wahl, die auch allesamt selbstgemacht sind - meine Wahl fiel auf die "Irn Bru BBQ Sauce", eine süß-würzige, dünnflüssige Barbecuesoße auf Grundlage des schottischen Nationalsoftdrinks Irn Bru. Sehr lecker! Darüber hinaus gibt es weitere, ausgefallene Soßen wie z.B. die "Whisky Jerk", eine karbisch angehauchte Variante mit Whisky.

Auch die Spare Ribs meiner Begleitung waren super und wie man das aus dem Smoker kennt: wunderbar zart, sodass sich das Fleisch fast schon nur vom Ansehen vom Knochen löst. Das Ganze lecker mariniert mit einem tollen Raucharoma.

Dazu bietet der Laden noch eine riesige Auswahl an Craft Bieren (Ich habe mich für das Brew Dog "This. Is. Lager!" entschieden, super!), kalte und warme Getränke und diverse Desserts.

Vorsicht: Der Laden schließt, sobald alles ausverkauft ist. Auch kann es vorkommen, das Nachmittags oder Abends verschiedene Gerichte schon aus sind - das steht dann auf einer Tafel über dem Tresen.


Klasse Laden, unbedingt empfehlenswert. Für mich ein Pflichtbesuch, wenn ich in Edinburgh bin.

WLAN-Passwort: meatandbeer

Der Name "Calton Hill" stammt vom gälischen "calltuinn" was in etwa Haselwäldchen bedeutet.
Auf dem Hügel befinden sich einige Denkmäler und Monumente, unter anderem das Scottish National Monument, dessen Bau 1829 nach 3 Jahren Bauzeit aufgrund Geldmangels eingestellt wurde und nun ein wenig aussieht wie die Überreste eines griechischen Tempels, das 1815 fertiggestellte und 2009 restaurierte Nelson Monument, das 1831 zu Ehren des schottischen Philosophen fertiggestellte Dugald Stewart Monument und das City Observatory, welches heute nicht mehr in Betrieb ist.

Calton Hil ist letztlich DER Ort in Edinburgh für eine schöne Sicht auf die Stadt und vor allem auch für schöne Aufnahmen der Innenstadt, vor allem der Old Town - das Titelbild wohl fast jedes Edinburgh-Reiseführers wurde von hier aufgenommen.
Wer also schöne Fotos mit nach Hause bringen oder sich einfach nur einen Überblick über die Stadt verschaffen möchte sollte unbedingt bei schönem Wetter den Calton Hill "besteigen" ;) Der Hügel ist vom Fuß zum höchsten Punkt etwa 46m hoch - das ist absolut machbar.

Super, klare Empfehlung!

Das Motel One an der Princes Street besticht vorrangig durch seine perfekte Lage im Herzen Edinburghs. Der Hauptahnhof Waverley Station liegt nur etwa 100m Luftlinie entfernt, hier halten auch die Airlink-Busse vom Flughafen sowie die "neue" Tram. Direkt gegenüber vom Motel One Princes Street liegt das Nobelhotel "The Balmoral", zur Royal Mile mit dem Edinburgh Castle an ihrem oberen Ende benötigt man zu Fuß maximal 5-10 Minuten.

Trotz der zentralen Lage ist es hier ziemlich ruhig. Wir hatten ein Zimmer zu einem der beiden kleinen Innenhöfe - bei geöffnetem Fenster konnte man Polizeisirenen in der Ferne hören, bei geschlossenem Fenster herrschte absolute Ruhe.
Insgesamt sind die Zimmer hervorragend gedämmt. Von den Nachbarn oder vom Flur her war ebenfalls nichts zu hören.

Die Zimmer waren - dadurch, dass dieses Hotel der Motel One-Kette noch recht neu ist - pikobello. Sauber, aufgeräumt und ohne erwähnenswerte Anzeichen von Verwohnung.
Die Zimmer sind natürlich verhältnismässig klein - eine Präsidentensuite sollte man hier nicht erwarten. Sie bieten allerdings absolut ausreichend Platz und sind clever durchdacht, sodass man auch ausreichenden Stauraum findet. Zudem sind sie modern und recht stylisch im typischen Motel-One-Stil gestaltet, inklusive Aquarium-Animation auf dem TV, sobald man den Raum betritt - nettes Gimmick. Die Ausstattung im Bad ist hochwertig und modern.
Ein besonders nettes Feature: Eine zusätzliche europäische Schuko-Steckdose neben dem Bett! Hat man seinen Adapter vergessen oder möchte mehr als nur ein Gerät anschließen, hat man hier die Möglichkeit.

Überrascht waren wir auch vom Service - wir wurden auf Deutsch begrüßt. Hängt wohl auch damit zusammen, dass Motel One eine deutsche Hotelkette ist und hier auch einige Deutsche arbeiten. Der Service war insgesamt sehr freundlich, aufmerksam und professionell.

Das Frühstück (9,50 GBP / Person) war übersichtlich und eher kontinentaler Prägung, aber in Ordnung. Die Frühstückslounge mit den großen Fenstern zur Princes Street hin ist großartig.
Für den gleichen Preis bekommt man allerdings auch in Edinburgh locker ein reichhaltiges "Full Scottish Breakfast" mit Getränk dabei. 

WLAN gibt es im gesamten Hotel kostenlos für bis zu drei Geräte.

Der Hoteleingang ist evtl. etwas schwierig zu finden. Steht man direkt vor dem Hotel, findet man im Erdgeschoss nur einen Apple-Store - ohne irgendeinen Eingang zum Motel One. Dieser befindet sich in der kleinen Seitenstraße um die Ecke, etwa 20m weiter. Von hier fährt man mit dem Aufzug in den ersten Stock zur Rezeption oder geht einfach die Treppe hinauf.

In Edinburgh existieren mittlerweile zwei Motel One-Ableger - einmal dieses hier, an der Princes Street und ein anderes, etwa 300m Luftlinie entfernt, an der Ecke Cockburn Street / Market Street [1]. Wir übernachteten während unseres Schottland-Trips am Anfang eine Nacht in dem einen und am Ende eine Nacht in dem anderen Motel One.
Hat man die Wahl zwischen beiden, sollte man sich definitiv für dieses Hotel hier entscheiden - es ist die um Welten bessere Variante! Ruhiger, kleiner, ansprechender gestaltet.


----
[1] http://www.yelp.de/biz/motel-one-edinburgh?hrid=ne5WhI1jUFOcRn-b-gAzHA

Kann eigentlich nicht meckern und die restlichen, vernichtenden Bewertungen nicht teilen.

Klar, das ganze Prozedere ist immer eigentlich viel zu langwierig und die Mitarbeiter versuchen einem immer irgendwelche Zusatzversicherungen aufzuschwatzen, die man nicht braucht oder schon hat. Aber sonst - nach meiner Erfahrung einfach eine typische Hertz-Autovermietung.

Am Tag, als ich meinen Mietwagen abgeholt habe, streikte das PC-System der Vermietung, weshalb das ganze Prozedere noch länger dauerte und alles ganz "oldschool" mittels Papierformularen erledigt werden musste. Okay, nervig, können die Mitarbeiter aber vermutlich nichts für.
Dafür gab es dann aber ein kostenloses Upgrade - von Kleinwagen auf Mittelklasse. Ein bisschen grenzwertig: die montierten Sommerreifen. Anfang März, bei einem Ausflug in die Highlands und zwischenzeitlich -1°C schon kritisch...

Die Filiale liegt verkehrsgünstig praktisch direkt an der Leith Street. Queen Street und Princes Street sind direkt nebenan, zum Flughafen braucht man etwa 30 Minuten.
Als Linksverkehr-Neuling ist die Lage allerdings unter Umständen schon eine Herausforderung - man startet praktisch direkt in einen großen, vielbefahrenen Kreisverkehr ;)

Etwas blöd: Es gibt hier keinen Kasten, in dem man die Schlüssel und Papiere bei Rückgabe deponieren kann. Will man den Wagen zwischen 18 und 8 Uhr abgeben, schaut man in die Röhre.

Wirklich toll! DIE Sehenswürdigkeit in Edinburgh, die ich jedem Besucher dieser schönen Stadt sofort empfehlen würde. So auf der Welt vermutlich einzigartig.

Großartige Atmosphäre - in diesem knapp 400 Jahre alten Gassenlabyrinth fühlt man sich wirklich wie ein Zeitreisender. Alles wurde so authentisch wie möglich belassen; Gassen, Türen, Fenster, sogar einige Räume.
Auch die Tourguides sind super und verstärken diese Atmosphäre noch einmal.

Meiner Meinung nach genau die richtige Mischung aus Touri-Gruselfaktor und Geschichte(n). Der relativ hohe Preis geht hier absolut in Ordnung.


Sinnvoll: Die Tickets vorher online oder bereits früh morgens buchen - so lässt sich der Tag besser verplanen.

Mercat Tours ist einer dieser Anbieter, die zahlreiche unterschiedliche geführte Touren durch Edinburgh anbieten. Dabei reicht das Angebot von Touren über die Royal Mile und durch die Old Town über diverse "Gruseltouren" bis hin zu privaten Führungen.

Highlight dabei: Mercat hat Zugang zu den Katakomben der Blair Street Vaults. Dieses verzweigte Tunnel- und Gewölbesystem ist entstanden, als man Ende des 18. Jahrhunderts damit begann, an den Seiten der South Bridge hohe Gebäude zu errichten. 18 der 19 Brückenbögen wurden somit zwischen diesen Gebäuden dieser ersten Einkaufsmeile Edinburghs eingeschlossen, nur der bis heute sichtbare Bogen am Cowgate blieb übrig.
Die eingeschlossenen Bögen wurden in Keller, Gänge und Räume unterteilt, es wurden Zwischenetagen eingezogen und die Räume zunächst als Lager und Werkstätten für die oben an der Brücke liegenden Geschäfte genutzt. Allerdings war die Brücke chronisch undicht - man hatte einfach vergessen, sie abzudichten. In einer regenreichen Stadt wie Edinburgh fatal... Die Nutzung der 120 Räume als Lager für kostbare Güter wurde also schnell aufgegeben und die Blair Street Vaults wurden verlassen. 
In den folgenden Jahren der industriellen Revolution wandelte sich die Gegend um Cowgate zu Edinburghs Slumgebiet, hier lebten die Ärmsten der Armen - die sich letztlich auch Wohnraum in den verlassenen Räumen unter den Bögen der South Bridge suchten. Die Gewölbe wurden berühmt-berüchtigt für Armut, Verbrechen, Prostitution und allerlei unerklärliche und schreckliche Geschehnisse, so sollen auch die bekannten "West Port murderers" Booke und Hare hier im 19. Jahrhundert ihr Unwesen getrieben haben und die Leichen an den Anatomieprofessor Doctor Robert Knox der nahegelegenen Universität verkauft haben.
Gegen Ende des 19. Jahrhunderts wurden die Räume nicht mehr genutzt, mit Müll und Schutt verfüllt und vergessen. Erst in den 1980ern wurden sie wiederentdeckt und erforscht. Seit den 1990ern bietet Mercat hier Führungen an.

Laut BBC zählen die Gewölbe unter der South Bridge zu "Britain's most haunted places" - nicht verwunderlich, bei den Geschichten, die sich um diesen Ort ranken. Noch weniger verwunderlich, dass Mercat also auch "Ghost tours" durch die Blair Street Vaults anbietet. Hierbei wird man von einem professionellen Guide und "Storyteller" geführt und bekommt allerlei gruselige Geschichten erzählt, das alles im Kerzenschein in den dunklen, feuchtwarmen Räumen.
Leider waren viele der Geschichten zu sehr offensichtlich aus den Fingern gesogen und die unzähligen Anmerkungen bei jeder Gelegenheit, was schon für unheimliche Dinge auf dieser und jener Tour passiert wären waren irgendwann etwas albern. Mag aber auch an mir persönlich liegen...
Trotzdem: Die Tour in die Gewölbe lohnt sich absolut und bietet einen interessanten Einblick in die Vergangenheit. Wer auf Geistertouren steht, kommt hier sicher auf seine Kosten. Ansonsten gibt es ja noch die klassischen History tours ;)

Vorbildliche Busverbindung vom Flughafen Edinburgh in die Innenstadt und zurück.

Die beiden Endhaltestellen der Buslinie 100 bilden dabei jeweils das Flughafenterminal und die Waverley Station in der Innenstadt. Dazwischen liegen etwa 10 über die Innenstadt verteilte Haltestellen und nur knapp 30 Minuten.
Der Bus fährt 24 Stunden täglich und kommt zu den Stoßzeiten im Abstand von wenigen Minuten.

An Bord des zweistöckigen Busses befinden sich videoüberwachte Gepäckablagen (unten), gemütliche Sitze, teilweise mit Tischen, Steckdosen und USB-Buchsen zum Laden des Smartphones und als kleines Extra gibt es kostenloses und recht flottes WLAN an Bord.

Relativ günstig ist das Alles auch noch: 4,50£ kostet eine einzelne Fahrt für einen Erwachsenen, 7,50£ die Hin- und Rückfahrt. Kinder zahlen 2 bzw. 3£.

Vom Flughafenterminal komfortabel direkt in die Innenstadt - das Ganze auch noch unkompliziert und bezahlbar. Was will man mehr...?!

Mittelgroßer, sehr übersichtlicher und aufgeräumter Flughafen.

Erreichbar ist der Edinburgh Airport hervorragend mit dem Airlink-Bus, der direkt von der Waverley Station in der Stadtmitte aus zum Flughafen pendelt. Hierfür braucht man etwa 30 Minuten, die Fahrt kostet knapp 7,50£. Seit einer Weile gibt es nun auch die Tram, die den Flughafen ebenfalls mit der Stadtmitte verbindet.

Die Check-In-Halle ist übersichtlich, zu den Abflügen gelangt man im zweiten Stock. 
Die Sicherheitskontrolle habe ich immer als sehr strikt aber auch als vorbildlich organisiert (man ist schließlich unter Briten), professionell und zügig erlebt.

Die Abflugshalle selbst ist ebenfalls übersichtlich, hier gibt es etwas mehr als 10 Gates, von einem Ende zum anderen braucht man maximal 10 Minuten.
Hier gibt es ebenfalls zahlreiche Cafes und Bars, Duty-Free-Shops sowie ein Running Sushi.

Es stehen zahlreiche Sitzgelegenheiten zur Verfügung, es ist sauber und es gibt ausreichend Toiletten. Die Beschilderung ist klar und übersichtlich und die Atmosphäre wenig hektisch und sehr angenehm.

Einen schottischen Whisky aus dem Duty-Free-Laden mitzunehmen lohnt sich meines Erachtens kaum. Die Preise sind hier immer noch recht hoch - in Deutschland sind die Flaschen kaum teurer, eher günstiger.

Location is everything and this hotel has it! The reception is inviting and open 24 hours. They are very helpful and have a lot of patience answering all my questions about where to go etc. there is also a lounge open 24 hours with snack-type food. Breakfast is continental-style so if you want heartier fare look elsewhere though you don't have to go far. The bus and train stations are right across the street so it's easy access to the airport or anywhere else you may want to go. Turn uphill to old town or cross the bridge to new town. The room with a view i got was spacious and comfortable though it's a bit of a maze to find it-just follow the signs. The windows are double paned so the room is quiet plus i was on the 5th floor which helps. It's a bit pricey but still one of the best values i found!

At the end of the terminal near gate 4, this lounge has a long list of airlines it says it's in partnership with, including Delta. I am a delta sky club member but that wasnt enough to get me in- it was my medallion status in the end. That makes no sense so they lost a star. Otherwise it's a small but comfortable lounge with salad bar, soup, snacks, sanwiches, plus small open service-only drink bar (no bar seating), and plenty of outlets around. Nice folks work here.

Full on bright and airy well-organized one-stop for organic snacks, body and hair-care, supplements, superfoods and more. There are always sales going on so check the prices. There was a buy one get one for half price sale on dr organic products this time plus you can ask for VAT refund form if u are visiting and get your tax back at the airport. Well located at the base of the south bridge and Princes Street. The gals working were super nice and knew where to find what i asked for but the store is well marked and organized and u can find what you need easily. A bit pricey but high quality.

My go-to place for really good food and live music that stirs but doesn't assault the senses!  I had a veggie tower that was flavorful and interesting from top to bottom at every bite! The gal behind the bar knew her whiskies and they have several tasting 'flights' or wine or soft drinks. My companions also raved about their meat dishes. There is history here yet with a  modern kitchen. The space can get tight so come early for a good table. The folks who come after dinner tend to stay. It's a multi-age place from what i've seen, mature youth to knee slapping elders. Prices are reasonable.

One of the most organized airports i've come through. Express bus to and from town or the nearby hilton hotel. Overpasses on the walkways if it's raining. Print your own luggage tag at the kiosks. Fast security process! Loads of employees helping. Nice folks. I feel like a human here. They walk you through the dury free shop first which lost a star- give me a choice whether i want to enter a shop! Otherwise there are food choices for all budgets plus lounges and a massage sp, plus bookstores and last-minute Clan-info shopping.

tips.text: Leave time to find parking!!!
No Delta skyclub in this large Intl' airport and not partnered with American
Get a return if you are coming from/going to the airport, it's cheaper!
Walking distance to the airport!!
Bus stop for express 100 bus to Edinborogh center right in front of hotel
They help you find the perfect whiiskey to try
Organized fast check in
Awesome location!!
The cheap room advertised on the window is for basic room off-season
Free wifi and full on continental breakfast with eggs
Delta sky club membership not accepted but if u are a Platinum u can get in
Easy to get to off the highway on the way to CLT airport!
Worth it! Ask for Jose!!!

reviews.text: Beautiful space, great location, staff rock. Tiny room, but this was expected. Bathroom amazing. Walls, however, paper thin, which is why I can barely string a sentence together in this review.

It's a chain, so not much to say here. 

Staff are friendly and very quick, bilingual (some polyglots), and decent pricing. WiFi excellent, no issue with plugs for my laptop. There's no view, but the outdoor seating is lovely. Very multicultural, multifaith area - I heard at least 9 different languages. 

My only complaint is that it's really, really dated inside. You can tell the staff do a great job of keeping it cheerful and clean. Everything is in good shape considering how busy it is (packed at times in the 6 hours I was there). Yet, still... It needs a revamp. It's dated, dreary, old, a bit run down. I almost didn't go in just based on the seating.

Service was surly and curt (go to the bar, no one will come to you). Breakfast was fast and tasty, if pricey. Filed up quickly but had privacy with a tiny booth in the back. Not the best, far from the worst, just... Okay. Enjoyed sitting here waiting for my flight.

Best hours of all the bio stores in the area (for me, that means they're open longer than anyone else). 

Small store packed with stuff, mostly packaged. It's much bigger than it looks from the outside. 

Local products in here I haven't found elsewhere, or at least nearby. 

Prices seemed on par with other nearby stores. 

My first choice if I need pills, aromatherapy, or packaged health foods in this area. 

Staff happy to help you find stuff, or at least they were when I went!

These are the kind of coffee shops/bistros that I search for when travelling as a nomad. 

There's free WiFi (look up, above the window for the code), dogs welcome, friendly service, a few plugs, small and quaint yet room to move, solid chairs and tables at a good height (really important for a writer!), food options that don't include bread or grains. 

It's right off the walk of Leith, around the corner from where I'm staying (uni housing turned into a hotel of sorts in the summer months), and has a lovely view. 

Add quick service, a great all day breakfast, non-chain, and I'm hooked. 

Why not five stars? Trying to reserve them for truly exceptional experiences... I may up it yet. ;)

Stopped in briefly to find something odd after the dollar store next door. They didn't have it, but, the staff member came out from behind the counter to help me look. Very friendly, excellent service, welcoming. I'd definitely return if I needed to.

I truly love this bio / health food store. Lots of organic fruits and vegetables, oftentimes local. A nice layout (although a bit tight if you have a backpack or use a cart), friendly staff, huge selection, and products that no one else in town carries (that I've noticed). 

It's my first choice when I want bio products. Prices on par with the other stores, but I find shopping here more pleasant. Just the vibe, no more, no less.

I love this place. Truly. It's great energy, the food tasty, they're mindful of allergies and food requirements. So why 4 stars? 

The price. 

I'm all for organic. It's all I aim to eat, and I'm learning the longer I'm in Toronto, the harder it is to find. 

So, I know my prices, and I'm aware of how to make most things on the menu. Many are time consuming, and as a staffer pointed out, "You can make the chocolate mousse at home easily. You can't the raspberry chocolate 'cake'". 

Still, $23 for a burger and a loony-sized salad seemed extreme. $13 for a piece of cake, same thing. 

Yes  it was delicious. I'll likely return. But the pricing is off. I mean, at least give me a handful of salad for my side. I literally finished what I had in one bite. 

The ambiance is coffee house hipster chill, the WiFi free, the staff friendly, the bathrooms clean. 

I'd sit here daily and work, if it were a bit more affordable.

My current roommate has me to in here all the time for stuff. I understand why, but, I'm not a fan of this store at all. 

Why go here then? They're the closest to us with the actual products we need. They have pills and packaged foods, aromatherapy supplies, that no one else carries. 

Why do I dislike it? The fresh produce leaves much to be desired. Some of the prices are ridiculous, and staff don't pipe up to say anything. So for instance, I grabbed some dried kelp in the spice section. Maybe 3 Tb worth. Over $10. Wtf? No one says... Hey, you sure you want this? You could get it for less if you did this ... Nothing. But when I complained, I'd already bought it. No refunds on spices that I packed up myself. 

Or, the staff. It's like you're in a bad 80s valley girl movie with all the sighing and eye rolling. "Oh my God, I GUESS I'll help you..." is the feel. And don't get in their way if they're at the back of the store, in the maze by the produce. You will get shoved out of the way. I did. Repeatedly. 

Finally, the prices. Maybe it's the area, but there's a definite markup here, beyond anyone else in town. 

Not a fan. Please, someone offer their breadth of products with a smile and I'm a customer for life.

I've spent a good amount of time in here on two separate visits. While all the DAVIDs Tea stores rock my casbah, this one gets special points for it's friendly staff. 

I'm still not sold on it being a concept store (as was described to me, "making DAVIDs Tea the Walmart of tea"), but, I do like that there's always "tea on tap". At the same time... I prefer loose leaf, and I can't see it saving anyone any real time to grab a pre-made sachet over a scoop of loose leaf. But, what do I know, I'm just a (nerdy, tea-obsessed) customer. 

Still, there's something really light and lovely about this store. I've visited many a DAVIDs, I've spent hours in the one at Metrotown (Burnaby, BC) -- and this one is the most inviting of all the ones I've visited. The seats at the front overlooking the street, the staff, the feel... it's just perfect. There's nothing awkward about the layout (as there is in the DAVIDs at the Toronto Airport). It's just... a peaceful refuge.

Why not 5-stars? Hm, it's hard to say exactly. Maybe it's the higher prices of late, or that everything comes pre-sweetened. (I want flavored matcha that I sweeten myself!) I dunno. It's just not the 5-stars that I want it to be. That is, until I go somewhere that there isn't a DAVIDs Tea again. Then, I miss this store specifically.

tips.text: Check in first to unlock 25% off your first stay!
Google maps puts this a block over and got me lost. Its on Rue Sainte-Paul E., on the same side as the Keg, and just across a size street from it.

reviews.text:
A hotel that has all the basics that you'd need - no additional fuss. For the price we paid, I'd say this place is actually pretty good value. The location is super central and it's easy to get to everywhere from here! It's also right next to the airport shuttle bus and train station, so transport is also easy. 

The insides is a bit of a maze depending on where your room is located - you may have to go down to go up to go back down again to get to your room! But no bother, it's good for walking off the chips and sobering from your drinks.

Came here for a wedding reception - really impressed with the quality of the food especially since we had such a large party. 

The bread came warm (mmm) 

Alizé Hot Appetizer Trio - 
1.Braised Veal with Truffled Potato Puree - this was REALLY good and by far my favorite from this restaurant. 
2.Grilled Fresh Water Shrimp, Curry Cream, Mango Chutney - a little overcooked
3.Seared Foie Gras with Toasted Brioche and Crème Anglaise

Phyllo Wrapped Baked Anjou Pear Salad - Roquefort Cheese, Fig Confiture, Spicy Pecans and Strawberry Vinaigrette - this was good but the fig confiture was a little too strong in flavor for me. However, everyone else in my table loved it.

For my entree I chose the King Crab & Truffle Stuffed Chicken Breast; it was a little salty but very creative and cute. The chicken was tender which I greatly appreciated. My boyfriend got the 12 oz. Austrailian Wagyu New York Strip which was VERY good. 

View is great! The one problem I had was...the bar directly downstairs is so loud it can get a little annoying for the diners at Alize.

To start...the woman behind the pastry counter was extremely rude and impatient...and simply looked bored and unhappy to be there. 

I got a Chocolate covered praline nougat...it was very pricey and way too sweet. The nougat isn't particularily nutty and definitely way too much and way too sweet. 

I also got a opera cake, napoleon, and creme brulee. The woman who packed the creme brulee didn't bother taping it down and so it spilled everywhere in the box(liquid sugar covering everything). It was just okay, nothing spectacular. 

The napoleon was also alright, nothing spectacular. I did like the opera cake but only get it if you REALLY like rich chocolate things (it can be kind of heavy towards the second half). I also ordered a cinnamon roll which was not bad; it was more of a danish flaky pastry than the typical fluffy cinnamon roll texture. 

On the side with gelato, we did order a coconut flavored one. It was very coconut-y and actually not bad. The guy behind the counter was much nicer and much more patient than the lady behind the pastries.

Overall, extremeley disappointed with quality of service and disappointed that the pastries weren't as spectacular as expected.

It's all about the ham and cheese sandwich and the chocolate almond croissant. I've been to the Yountville Bouchon bakery and the Columbus (NYC) Circle one. I've got to say though, Yountville Bouchon still has the best quality. The wait for this one though isn't as bad but the selection isn't as big. 

If you ever get a chance, visit Yountville Bouchon Bakery and be amazed.

First off let me warn you - Las Vegas prices are $$$ and Shake Shack is definitely one of those places that're overpriced. But that doesn't mean the food wasn't good! It was great! I got the Smokestack - and it was perfect, chilies and all! The fries aren't usually the type I'd go for but they came crispy so I was happy. 

I ended up going back in the long queue (which moves pretty quickly) and getting a milkshake (vanilla). The small one is small, so if you're looking to share maybe get a larger one. The shakes are super thick so it's great if you're into frozen custard.

I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and taste of the food! 

The server did a good job dealing with the chaos (multiple people yelling multiple orders and being indecisive) at our table of 10+. Service was a bit slow, but understand that it was because they wanted to serve our large table all at once. 

The burgers are actually really good - I was surprised at the quality and taste. The burgers are on the smaller side though, so definitely get some chips on the side. 

There's lots of milkshake options, and you can add liquor if you want something extra.

This place was PACKED! Came in for a juice and a snack. The coffees here are really good, and the smoothie I got (forgot which one) was good but pretty sour. I recommend getting some frozen yogurt in there if you get one of the vitamin c packed smoothies. We also tried their desserts: the "raw" snickers cake was pretty good! 

There's lots of healthy options and vegetarian options if that's something you're looking for. We didn't try any, but definitely would next time.

Sage was amazing! The food was perfect and it had a nice ambiance although it was still casual. The prices of the drinks are a bit high, but they're damn good. They also have absinthe fountains in case you're interested. 

If you don't choose to go for the tasting, you can go for 2,3, or 4 course options. Everything is great. If you're a wagyu fan the supplementary cost is worth it. The scallops as a main were epic. Dessert was creative and yummy (it's on a separate menu), so save room.   

Our server may have cracked one too many jokes but hey, at least he was nice.

Make sure you reserve a table beforehand! It was packed, and loads of walk-ins had to be turned away. We got extremely lucky and promised to eat in under 45 minutes, so were able to to nab a table. 

The food was really good and portions were decently large. Definitely go for the garlic naan which is packed with amazing flavor. We also ordered a prawn biryani that came with a lovely sauce and chicken korma curry. The food was great, and the service was friendly.

I'd heard/seen Serendipity 3 in NYC and kept hearing about this frozen hot chocolate drink. I guess it was finally time to try it (as there was no line when I walked by). 

The first sip is like 'woah this is....frozen...hot chocolate' but the next few sips you get sick of the drink. It's just way too sweet and very hard to swallow after the inital sip. A little too pricey and so I don't think I'll be getting this again, or recommending it to any friends.

Mmm the bread came with this carrot spread - so delicious; that was probably one of the highlights. We got great seating (a four person table all to my boyfriend and I) with a lovely view of the Bellagio fountains. 

We were craving french onion soup (onion soup au gratin) and this hit the spot! There's a generous amount of gruyere cheese in the soup; so ooey-gooey delicious. 

My boyfriend and I shared the filet mignon merlot, it was nice but nothing super special. 

One complaint is that our server didn't seem to know much about wine recommendations...other than that the food came quickly and was above average quality.

Pricey, great service, decent food. We got atoasted roast beef panini which was actually pretty enjoyable. The tomato veggie soup was not bad either. 

I also ordered the 6 dollar cup of grapefruit juice. It was good, but the price is not so good (as expected of Vegas). 

The people who were working there were extremeley friendly and helpful. That's definitely a plus.

I actually had a fantastic experience at Eiffel tower restaurant for lunch. We came with no reservations and had to wait about 10 minutes, but where we were seated had an amazing view of the Bellagio fountains. 

Quick tip on drinks - the nonalcoholic drinks are yummy but have a tad too much syrup in them. Ask for club soda to be mixed in to make it less overpowering. 

We started with the creamy French Onion soup - I've never had french onion soup in this form (creamy) before but it was really yummy. 

Next  we ordered the ocean seafood salad (lobster, shrimp, crab) to share. It came pre-tossed with really delicious dressing. All the ingredients were super fresh and it was a pretty large serving (do share with someone if this is not your main course). 

Finally we ordered the Petite New York Strip steak with cabernet butter - yum! I usually like my meat cooked medium, but this could have been a little rarer. The flavors were great and the cabernet butter went perfectly with the steak. 

Service was impeccable and the servers were all speedy and very helpful. I'd definitely recommend this restaurant for lunch.

Definitely not work the money. Sure it seems like you have a decent amount of options, but everything is so dry and bleh. I had to mask all of my plate with sweet an sour sauce that they offered.

The only thing edible in the desserts section was the chocolate chip cookies. The cream in the cream puffs was a strange...and translucent. The cheesecake was more like a thick cheese-y jello on pie crust.

You're better off forking out another 10 dollars and eating at a better buffet!

Bouchon for brunch - best idea ever. Maybe I just made the right decision for my order...chicken and waffles all the way. 

We started with some freshly fried beignets; always a yummy option. But really, they're just donut holes with a side of vanilla butter and fruit jam. 

The American breakfast is a great deal. Two people in my table ordered this; they chose to go with the chocolate almond croissant which is a MUST. It's one of the most amazing creations in the pastry world (at least that's my opinion ;-p). The breakfast itself also comes with a nice fresh toasted bricohe and eggs done your way. 

I ordered the chicken and waffles; so good. I've had good experience with Thomas Keller and chicken (Yountville Ad Hoc fried chicken...ughhhhhhh...sooooo good). His restaurant's just...KNOW how to do chicken. It was so tender and juicy, and the perfect amount of seasoning. Waffles were savory, which is new for me, but I love sweet and salty so it was all just too good to be real. 

Bouchon brunch - do it.

tips.text: Roast beef panini toasted is pretty good

reviews.text:
Stayed here for two nights, costs was £109 per night for two people sharing a room which was not a budget price for what felt like budget rooms. Firstly they don't have any twin rooms in the hotel which would be preferable when I was sharing with a friend not my lover! There is only one small bin which is located in the bathroom.  No soap, which I find ridiculous, only toiletries were a dual shower gel/hair wash. There was a hairdryer but no wardrobes or drawers. Room was also very cold. 

Now for the positive, the location is very good, close to princes street and St. Andrews square. The staff are very helpful and the bar is 24 hours. 

Don't bother with the breakfast which is £9.50 each for a continental breakfast where you can easily get a cooked breakfast in any one of the cafes in Cockburn Street, which is adjacent to this hotel. 

If I go to Edinburgh again I will book a different hotel.

Don't bother. I note that other reviews for this cafe are by personal friends of the owner which maybe why they have scored high. 

We originally sat outside as there were no tables available, however moved inside as soon as a table became available as it was cold. We told the staff at the counter but they seemed unable to pass this info on. As first our drinks were taken outside and then we saw our food going the same way. When we stopped the gentleman who was serving our food he was quite rude about us moving tables! 

My fried egg was undercooked and the bacon was poor quality. It was cheap but I would recommend paying a bit more and going to Southern Cross Cafe just up the road, unless of course you want poor quality food and bad service.

Went here with a large group of friends on a Friday evening. The staff were very helpful, when we originally booked we didn't know how many there would be, we started off at 5 and ended up with 18. They let us have a semi private room which was fab for us and the other guests as we were a bit noisy.  They phoned us to confirm a few details and were just great. 

I had the duck breast and sweet potato side which were just delicious. Every single person in our party really loved their food. 

Actually I can find no fault in their restaurant hence the first 5 star review I have ever given!

Went to this place for lunch as a friend had eaten here before and recommended it. 

We couldn't find a table initially but were able to share with some other people. The service was good and the food fabulous. I had the salmon salad and the salmon was superb. My friend had haggis neeps and tatties, which were heavenly. 

The decor is lovely with high ceilings and a central bar. Very spacious area, in a good location. Although not on the main road so not many people stumble across this, glad we got a recommendation.

I am not sure what went wrong on the day I visited as reading other reviews this sounded like a great place. The decor is great and quirky and the menu looked good. The gentleman that initially served us was pleasant as was the lady who took our order and served our food. 

However the food was not good. Pasta bake was too wet and much too much cheese. The haggis, neeps and tatties too dry. The mince with Yorkshire pud was made from very poor quality mince and was probably just purchased from Iceland. Worst of all was, I told them I was wheat and dairy free, I checked before I started eating my food if the waitress had checked and she said she had. Well she hadn't as I was ill later on. 

I would not recommend you go here if you like good quality food

Good place to go for breakfast, they even did gluten free bread. They are very busy so be prepared to wait during peak times. I found upstairs warm but my companion didn't. My friend likes her breakfast well done and they did a fabulous job. I had poached egg, bacon and gluten free bread and it was well cooked. My friend had a full Scottish breakfast and she ate it all. 

Great place for breakfast

Well, i like the idea of Motel One. Always in the center of the city, somehow modern design, good beds. No fancy unnecessary stuff. All of this is true for this motel one in Edinburgh. Perfectly located even if it's hard to discover. 
Breakfast is ok, but not more. 
Service is friendly. 
No twin rooms available..
Nice Thai restaurant, very friendly service, good food & moderate prices.

I really do love the Germans. This chain is spreading fast over there and they're bringing their efficiency and attention to detail with them here. 

Motel One is, as the name suggests, aimed at the budget market. Rates for this venue range from approximately £69/night up. I booked ahead and appreciated the completely free reservation process with room guaranteed until 6pm on the day of arrival. If you give your credit card details, it's reserved beyond that time.

Location is excellent! If you exit from the Market St side of Waverly and turn right it's maybe 3 minutes away. It would be very hard to have it closer. That also makes it very close to the castle and Princes St. Welcome was warm and check-in easy. The lobby area is pretty small but clean and cosy with sweets, maps etc. There's a bar area down a few steps where they also serve the buffet breakfast each morning.

My room was the cheapest version and was internal, facing onto a courtyard. It had no view and was quite dark, but quiet. Everything was completely spotless. The bathroom was small but well designed and had a great shower. Bed was comfy with 2 single duvets. So continental, don't you know? I appreciated the tea and coffee making facilities (I'm like a beast without them), the decent sized TV and the free wifi. The hanging storage facilities are limited but it was fine for a few days. 

Random: hands down the best hotel hairdryer I have ever used. And one of the best dryers in general-called a Black Mambo. It was worth staying there for that alone. Well, you know, also the really good value and the pristine conditions. But definitely the hairdryer.

This is the latest addition to feed my Shoppers Drug Mart addiction.  I strolled in laden down with groceries on the opening day, looking like a vagrant, but was treated like a red carpet worthy customer.  I was served by Maxine, the beauty manager, and she was simply lovely.  Very sweet, knowledgeable, sense of humour and not at all pushy.  I walked out happier than when i walked in and it was purely based on service received; not the cut price package of Pirate cookies that made it into my basket.

The store itself is medium sized but seems to pack pretty much everything in.  You have to scoot by the Beauty Boutique to get to the main part which is pretty sneaky.  It's so hard to resist all those shiny, colourful (and expensive) things.  It's a well stocked Beauty Boutique too with the usual Lancome, Clarins, Elizabeth Arden etc as well as Lise Watier, Benefit etc.   The rest of the store is sparkling (well, it is new) and full of the usual mixture of a few groceries, medications, cosmetics etc.  Staff were genuinely pleasant and everybody seemed happy to be there.

This one is  a keeper.  I'll definitely be adding it to my list of places to spend money!

I'm struggling to decide on my stars for this gym. I think it's a 3.5?

 

This was formerly Extreme Fitness but is now a GoodLife so think it deserves a new listing. One of the main deterrents from joining previously was the very aggressive sales from Extreme and the many unhappy customers with billing problems. GoodLife doesn't seem to have quite so many issues so hopefully this won't be the case.

 

The gym itself is a nice space-very loft-like which is kind of appropriate for the Entertainment District location. There are lots of exposed pipes and polished concrete on the staircases etc. More importantly, it's clean. The changing rooms are actually pleasant and spotless with a little lounge area and hair straighteners! I wanted to stay there for the whole morning but I usually go to McCaul which is a complete dive and makes this place appear spa-like in comparison.

 

Equipment is spread out over 2 floors. Lots of cardio machines which are pretty new and appear to work! That's another welcome surprise after going to McCaul. They're mainly a mix of Life Fitness and Precor. Love the built-in TVs. Such a relief not to have to fight over channel choice with a roomful of people. Weight section is decent enough. Dumbbells over 100lbs, a few squat racks, graded barbells...and a ton of machines for people that are into it. No kettlebells or TRX on the floor, sadly. Flooring is a mix of carpet and rubber. There is also a little "Fit-Fix" room which has some dumbbells, balls and mats in the corner and there's a separate personal training studio. THAT'S where they hide the kettlebells. They're apparently planning to add TRX training but it will presumably be limited to personal training clients only.

 

There's a pretty wide range of classes including spinning and the times are convenient too.

 

Staff seem to be mainly former Extreme employees. The guy on the desk this morning was pleasant! Some of the trainers from McCaul GL are moving here and they're nice guys so that bodes well.

 

Random points: juice bar if you want to replenish any calories you might have burned and add a few extra for good measure. There's also a little business section with computers and a health centre.

 

Opening hours: 5am to midnight weekdays, 8am-8pm weekends

 

Overall: nice place! I'll have to check it out again during peak times though. Minus marks for not allowing the normal members to use kett

Another weekend, another attack on my debit card at Lululemon.  But somehow they make you leave the situation feeling happy.  It's a wonderful talent!

This store was on Bloor until a few days ago apparently.  I wandered in as part of my search for comfy lounging/pottering around the place trousers (pants).  The excess ice-cream of the summer has resulted in a marked reduction in wearable items in my wardrobe, sadly.  But, I digress!  This branch, despite being in upmarket Yorkville, still retains a really friendly feel and a relaxed atmosphere.  All the staff were really smiley and friendly and I managed to seek out the trousers I wanted no problem.  As I left the changing room, the assistant asked how I got on.  I replied that I was going to buy them but would have to shorten them.  She informed me that they hem them FOR FREE.  I hopped up on a stool and she pinned them-they should be ready in a few days.  And they keep them for up to a year!

The good:
-Gorgeous clothes
-Great yoga accessories
-Friendly staff
-Free yoga on Sundays at 10am
-Free hemming!

The bad:
-The stuff is pricey.  But you knew that.

The ugly:
-My face when I realise I can't have it all...

I've almost completely given up on my dreams of being rich and famous, so a trip to the VIP cinema is about as close as I become to feeling special.  I love it there.  Special side of the cinema, away from all the normal people, small screening room so you feel like it's a preview or in some way better than seeing the movie everywhere else, people who bring your order....and wine!  The seats are really comfy and recline a little so it's like being at home-but better.  Wine is pricey but having a full bottle wouldn't really enhance the experience anyway!

I've also tried the regular cinema and it was also good.  The last day I went it was strangely chilly in the theatre though so I ended up sitting with my coat over me.   Heating is probably a good idea for winter.  I also decided to live with my thirst when I realised a bottle of water from the vending machine costs $3.50.

I really like it here and I will definitely be back...especially now that I have my Scene loyalty card.  I'm determined to save my points and get a free movie!

I've become a bit Dollarama obsessed. This one is a bit "People of Walmart" and feels kind of poky but still manages to have a huge selection of everything. I love the cheapness. And I love that I can find pretty much everything in here from chocolate to feather boas through stuff for the garden I don't have, stickers and generic Pepcid. I've spent many, many happy minutes wandering up and down the aisles in some kin of fugue state wondering if I need a garden gnome for my balcony, or if I have any use for a packet of Canada pencils. The housewares are actually pretty good and you can't compain about mugs for $1.25. I also really like their 74% cocoa chocolate which is a steal for $1.50/100g. I think I prefer it to Lindt!

Downsides-slightly dodgy patrons at times and a mildly scruffy look. But I'll completely take that for the savings. I'm a fan.

Great experience!

I was specifically looking for somewhere that offered IMS (intramuscular stimulation) which is a type of dry needling. I'd had really good results with the technique previously and wanted to try it on my tight calves. A Facebook friend mentioned being treated here so I did a bit of investigating. 

They're really quick to answer emails and very helpful! It took a while to organise an appointment-a mixture of them being busy and me having to work. When we managed to coordinate schedules, it was really easy. I was allowed to book by email and got a time that suited me!

The space is really lovely. It's all open in the centre with lots of light and shiny wood floors. Individual treatment rooms are off to the side which was really nice. Can't say I love going to physio and being in a row of beds as if it's an old style ward. I like my privacy! Especially when I'm paying for it.

My reception was friendly and I was given the usual intake forms and then it was just a short wait before my physio arrived. I had Carl who was fabulous. Really friendly, very thorough and excellent clinically. He picked up on stuff without me telling him which is always a good sign. He also didn't just look at my calves-he was more holistic and system-based which I also liked. There were moments when I didn't completely love him (like when he was putting needles into my chronically tight muscles) but overall I have only praise for him! I particularly liked it that he didn't try to book me in for more sessions. It was left open-ended...I can go back if I need to. I don't like being stuck going back forever and ever.

Rates are pretty standard I think. It's $110 for the first session which is stated to be 45 minutes. I think it was at least that if not slightly longer. Follow-ups are $60 for 20 minutes and $70 for 30 mins. I think most places are that expensive though. And I escaped with a one-off. Think my calves feel better. Despite disregarding all the post-procedure advice. Sorry Carl!

Perhaps I was unlucky, but I can't really go over 3 stars after my first experience in David's Tea.  I have been trying to cut down on my junk food this week but decided to allow myself Sunday treats.  The friendly girl in Little Nicky's had recommended the cupcakes in David's Tea so I just had to try them.

The so-so rating is purely based on poor service.  The Australian girl ignored the 2 customers (including me)  for ages while she chatted with the girl who was delivering boxes of cupcakes.  Eventually she got iced tea for the other person who had obviously been waiting since before I entered.  I asked about cupcake flavours.  There were 5 cakes on display, 3 flavours.  One was drumstick.  I asked what that was and she said "like the ice-cream" and turned away.  That didn't help since I have no idea what drumstick is so opted for peanut butter.  I remarked that the selection in the boxes that had been delivered looked better but she wouldn't let me have one because she hadn't sorted through them.

Cupcake-excellent.   Small but really yummy.  Probably the best I've had in Toronto so far.  $2.86 after tax.  If I could find the person who makes them I would set up a direct debit for a selection each and every weekend with extras on special occasions.   I've been incredibly disappointed by most cupcakes around so far but loved this.

The shop itself is really cute with a wide variety of teas and lovely colourful tea paraphernalia.

Service today though was rude, disinterested and unhelpful.  I didn't dare to ask about teas in case I would get my head bitten off.  Maybe I'll summon up the courage next time.  Or go back for more cupcakes.  But I'll check who's working there first....

Recently opened nail bar in Village By the Grange. I stopped in last week because they had just opened and had 50% off all services. I was lucky that there happened to be a lull when I strolled by at 3pm on Saturday and they could take me without an appointment-apparently half the neighbourhood had descended on them to take advantage of the special offer.

I decided on a shellac manicure-full price $35. I think I might have ended up with the owner. He definitely had divided attention. The boys who were on reception didn't seem to have a clue what they were doing and he was mainly talking to them and jumping up occasionally to sort things out. He didn't talk to me too much except to encourage me to come again. And he did thank me for trying them. My nails looked good when I left but are showing some wear and tear now after a week, when I'd hope to get 2 good weeks out of shellac. I like it that he gave me the buffer and file he'd used to take home!

Prices aren't overly cheap at full price but not super expensive. For example: manicure is $16, pedicure $26, 60 min massage is $70 and full leg waxing $45. There will apparently be 20% off for a while until they get established.

Overall it was fine. I'm going to try again and see if the organisation and attention improve once the crazy first week is over. My feet are like little hooves at the moment so it's probably worth the investment.

I was trying to think of a reason to have this less than 5 stars...but couldn't!  I'm not sure my memories are actually that clear though-once I walked in the door and saw bins full of bulk goods as far as the eye could see I entered a kind of fugue state and just started shovelling things into little plastic bags.

They really do have everything.  I was feeling a bit naughty the day I went so didn't pay too much attention to anything vaguely healthy but they seemed to have every type of flour, powder, seed and nut.  I couldn't decide what I wanted either-every type of chocolate chip and disc, chunks, sprinkles, malt balls.... I think my serum glucose levels shot up just looking at the array of multicoloured jellies, sweets and sherbets.

There's also a great selection of UK chocolate bars for when anybody (e.g. me) is craving UK/Irish treats.

The more I think about this place, the more I think I need to go back to stock up!

This Druxy's is in the lobby of Princess Margaret Hospital.  Catering options are limited there-Tim Horton's or here.  I can't cope with Tim's coffee anymore so started popping in here instead.  I've only had coffee and snack things so far.  The rest of the food is like any Druxy's I think.

Coffee is decent but the 4 star rating is more for the staff.  They are so friendly and cheerful.  One woman in particular tends to be on the cash register in the mornings and truly does brighten my day.  Yesterday's exchange:
Me: Extra large coffee please.  It's one of those days.
Her: I thought all the days were like that?  Haha!
Too true....
She doesn't have to be so cheerful and smile so genuinely, but she does and I feel energized leaving-even before I've sipped my coffee!

Prices are good too-$1.25 for a large coffee, $1.50 for the extra large/jumbo sized.

My headache is gone!  3 days of popping Advil and feeling not quite right with a niggly headache that I knew was coming from my neck and all gone after an hour under the magic hands of Johnny Vos.

I was lucky enough to come across the recent Fabfind deal for discounted massages at Vos Massage Therapy.  I had a look at the website and was impressed by the photos and the bios of all the therapists.   I took what seemed like a risk at the time and bought 2 vouchers.  It's now seeming like one of my best decisions!

I made my appointment around a week ahead of time.  The process was made incredibly easy by the online booking system which allows you to book by date/time/service and therapist.  They're open every day (with evenings on weekdays) so it's pretty easy to get an appointment.  I decided on Johnny Vos and a Sunday appointment.  They emailed with a reminder the day before.  I loved it that I didn't have to try to sneak a phone call to book in work or get calls I couldn't answer to remind me.

The clinic is on King St East and is accessed through a door right next to Petite Thuet.  The welcome from Johnny was warm and I felt comfortable immediately.  I settled down to my medical history form with a glass of water before we got started.  One of the other therapists was around and was also smiley and welcoming.  It made for a lovely atmosphere!

We headed into the treatment room which was cosy, restful and spotless.  We had a chat about my aches and pains, my job and how it contributes to my issues and any relevant medical history.  I got to pick music for the session and was then told that there were two rules.  Rules?  Eek!  Turned out they were that I was to let him know if he was hurting me-he could modify the technique to alleviate it; and that I was to ask any questions I wanted.  Best rules ever!

The massage was fantastic.  I'm picky and know a good massage.  I had a few trusted people at home who kept me mobile and clung onto them because there is nothing I hate more than a bad massage with someone who doesn't know what they're doing.  I hate it when it's too light/feathery strokey but also don't particularly enjoy the ones that are too pokey.  This was neither.  It was, quite simply, perfect.  He worked every bit of me from my toes to the top of my head and left me so loosened out and relaxed that speaking seemed like an effort.  The knots in my neck and shoulders were gently teased out so that I could move my neck like a normal person by the end.  He used a variety of massage techniques and heated pads throughout the treatment and checked in regularly to ensure that I was comfortable and the pressure was OK.  He knew when to chat and when to stay quiet and was careful at draping so that I never felt exposed.

On the way out, he handed me a bag of bath salts fragranced with the oils I had chosen for my massage and instructions to use them that night.  As he predicted, the bath and the scent relaxed me all over again and left me ready for bed (even though I'd also napped on the couch-was barely able to keep my eyes open after the treatment!).  I had a great sleep and woke feeling more refreshed than usual.

The whole experience was completely deserving of a 5 star "woohoo! As good as it gets!" rating.  Everything from booking to walking out the door was flawless.  The treatment was excellent and I was treated extremely well-like a favourite client, even though it was my first time there.  Johnny couldn't have been nicer-he's one of those people you just can't help but like--and he's also talented at what he does.  Having read through the bios on the website, it seems like all the therapists (registered massage therapists and acupuncturist) who work there are equally passionate about what they do so I'm confident a treatment from anyone involved would lead to equally floaty happy feelings!  

I actually considered not posting this review-if they get more business it might make it harder for me to get an appointment-but my conscience wouldn't allow me to keep it a secret.  Everybody deserves a good massage.  I know I've found my place now!

I'm liking this new Bulk Barn! 

Bulk Barn is dangerous for me. Too many delicious things that I just have to eat. Sweets, chocolates, cookies, chocolate covered nuts, trail mixes.... I love their sunflower seed butter and sometimes dream about their "clowning around" trail mix and the bins of chocolate chips. They also have healthier things like quinoa, oatmeal, spices, teas, coffee beans etc and non-bulk items like nut milks, British chocolates and pretty much everything you could need for baking. 

I prefer this store to Carlton St. The layout is a little nicer and the bins are smaller with a place for the spoon. Check-out was slow because it has just opened and the assistant was being trained in. Having been there for the first week of Carlton St though, I'm pretty confident that they'll all by up to speed within no time. Great location too, close to St Lawrence Market and No Frills. Just don't forget the lovely Domino Foods downstairs in SLM. They deserve some business too!

I know some people think of going to the hairdresser as a kind of treat/spa session.  They see it as a pampering, relaxing experience.  Me?  I'd have root canals without anaesthetic more willingly usually.  I have hairdresser phobia.  I found a good hairdresser at home and refused to go to anyone else, even when I moved 150 miles away.  An addiction to Tabatha's Salon Takeover took my phobia to new levels. Basically, it's hard for a hairdresser to impress me.  

I bought a Living Social coupon for a cut price cut, scalp treatment and blow dry at Darren Kwik's salon.  I decided to take a chance on using it-despite my fear of places without personal recommendations or multiple Yelp reviews. I hate having to phone so decided to try emailing about getting an appointment, fully expecting to hear nothing.   I was shocked and thrilled to get a speedy response and a time slot on the day I wanted!  It was so efficient and easy.

Anyway, I kind of feel sorry for Darren and the challenge he faced on Saturday when I arrived into him.  I'd been to the gym so my hair was a mixture of damp and frizzy and dragged into a ponytail.  I'd thrown on shorts and a t-shirt after the gym so to say I looked "casual" is to put it kindly.  I left home too late so ended up jogging along a good bit of Queen West to his salon just slightly west of Trinity Bellwoods.  He was therefore landed with a glowing, scruffy, frizzy haired mess expecting him to make me pretty!

He rose to the occasion with not the slightest bother and was as calm as I was flustered.  His consultation was unhurried and really excellent.  I think he's the first stylist I have ever had who immediately worked from the fact that my hair is naturally curly/wavy and that I'd want a cut that would suit it curly or straight.  He talked about cutting layers to frame my face.  I asked him to try to keep the length in my hair.  He solved my query about why my hair felt so thin by pointing out how thin the longest layers had been cut previously.   He somehow managed not to be derogatory even when I told him it was ratty/wispy/terrible!  He didn't even scold me for colouring my own hair-he just gave advice on how to minimise damage.

I liked that the salon is small (just 4 stations) and cosy.  It felt so calm and relaxing in there.  Everything was spotless and comfortable.

He washed my hair himself and gave me what was hands down the best scalp massage I've had in years and years.  I thought I was going to fall asleep on the chair!  We then settled into the main business of cutting.  He was reasonably quick-but in an experienced way, not in a rushing through it way.   His version of taking an inch off the ends was more like 3 inches...but to be honest I think it needed it.  I do wonder if a hairdresser's inch is a special measurement like a baker's dozen though.  I don't think I've ever had an actual inch cut off!  He chatted away a little while he was cutting but would have let me stay quiet if I wanted I think.  I sipped my coffee happily as he worked away.

When it came to drying my hair, he asked what look we were going for and I blurted out "partyish" because I was actually going to a party that night.  He somehow managed to know exactly what I wanted and gave me a flicky look with movement and volume!  I swanned out the door with a new spring in my step and my hair looks much thicker and healthier after him.  He gave tons of advice on hair care without once pushing any particular product.  It was a pleasant experience and I gave the cut its real test this morning when it was time to dry it myself.  It went well!  It was much more manageable than before and he actually managed to keep a lot of the length.  I may have found my Toronto hairdresser!

It's actually difficult to rate these cupcakes in a way.  We were treated to them in work by someone who had spent a few weeks there and it was a lovely gesture so I feel a little bad writing a negative review.  The company delivered the cupcakes to work (downtown) for her which I thought was great service.  The cakes looked great.  Some were just regular cupcakes but others were decorated with fantastic chocolate lollies.  Because it was a hospital setting they had moulded lollies of nurses, bandaids, bones etc.  Very cute!
Unfortunately, cupcakes aren't purely about the cute factor.  They're also meant to taste good.  The cake was pretty good-a light and airy chocolate.  The frosting was disgusting.   I will quite happily eat frosting all by itself usually but ended up spitting this out and dumping the whole thing.  It's not buttercream, it's not cream cheese; it's some kind of grainy, synthetic, whipped entity that just tastes of chemicals.  Generally if something has fat and sugar in it, I'll eat it but I had to draw the line when it came to these cupcakes.
I liked the delivery and they looked so cute.  It was a shame that they were essentially inedible.  Is buttercream that difficult to master?!?

I wanted to check a couple of bloods so pottered along to my friendly local family doctor, Dr Stendardo at Appletree in Village by the Grange (http://www.yelp.ca/biz/appletree-medical-centre-toronto).  It was another efficient visit.  He printed off the necessary forms and I trotted off.  The laboratory indicated was this Gamma-Dynacare on Edward Street nearby.

I Googled beforehand and found some one star reviews so I wasn't particularly hopeful.  I was worried about long waits because I knew I'd have to pop out of work to get the test done (their hours are pretty much office hours) so phoned one afternoon to enquire.  I was told I could go in right then if I wanted and the wait wouldn't be long.  I went the next afternoon instead.  It was the day before Canada day, just before a long weekend so I thought it would be busy and chaotic.  It was anything but.  The lab is on the 8th floor and I strolled right in with my form and OHIP card and presented them at the desk.  The friendly reception staff started entering my details and then directed me to a cubicle.  I had barely sat down when the phlebotomist came in to take my sample.  He was friendly and quick.  I barely felt the needle and next thing I knew I was collecting my OHIP card and heading back to work.  Couldn't believe how quick and easy the process was.  There had to be a catch!

There was no catch.  I was called to get my results the following Wednesday which was pretty efficient considering the long weekend in between.  No wait, friendly people, skilled phlebotomist and pretty rapid turnaround time?  Yes, I'm a fan!

So happy to see this place here, so close to home! Well; happy sad. I'm on a budget and this is far too much temptation for me.

I'd read about Titika on a lululemon lover's blog as an alternative for lululemon addicts. I browsed the website and was interested to see what the clothes looked like in real life. It was so exciting to see a real life store a few weeks later!

This location opened on September 22nd-I missed it because I was away but was in here this weekend to have a good old browse. It's like lululemon with an edge and I think better quality too. It's most certainly pricey-think $50+ for a tank top-but they have some lovely pieces. I left with one black top which I love today but have my eye on a few other things in there too. If I was in a slightly better place financially I would have left with lots more. The quality is excellent and they have some really unusual detailing on their tanks and tops. They do run a bit roomy though so it's likely you'll be sizing down. Got to love vanity sizing-particularly in athletic wear!

Staff are super friendly. They even coped with my quite grumpy Sunday "I'm wearing my ipod-don't bother me" mood with good humour. They were fantastic for getting new sizes and recommending items/the correct size. The store itself is bright, clean and a really pleasant place to shop. It's not cluttered and is merchandised well. I even love their bags!

I have a sneaking suspicion that I'll be upgrading this place to 5 stars soon. I love that it's a Toronto based company that is growing. I'm looking forward to seeing more of the fall/winter line. What I'm not looking forward to is trying to either stop myself from buying anything here or trying to figure out how to pay the visa. Maybe they'd let me work for clothes? I should email them!

High expectations really do set you up for a fall.  Even worse, I decided to wait until my birthday to visit here.  I spent ages reading through the extensive menu online, plotting and planning.  I went to the gym to earn my waffle(well, maybe 1/4 of it) and went in excited.  I suppose it couldn't really live up to the hype.

I wanted a waffle with ice-cream but they had none.  I settled on mixed berries instead.   Eat in or out?  I wanted in.  It's cheaper and you get plates.  I also ordered coffee which is self serve with the bonus of free refills.  Total came to $10 which was more than I expected.  I got plenty of time to ponder the arithmetic as I waited and waited.  The menu said my waffle was $8 and coffee was $1 (tax included).  I'm no mathlympian but that's $9 the way I see it.  Eventually the cause was revealed when I was handed a to-go polystyrene container.  She'd messed up the order and forgotten I wanted it there.   And charged me extra.  The girl cooking (her daughter) scooped my waffle and fruit back out and onto a plate.

The food?  It looked good, despite the extra travel between containers.  Couple of slices of pineapple and melon.  Few fresh strawberries.  Sadly the rest of the fruit was mushy and preserved in syrup.  The waffle was OK but quite soggy and not especially tasty.  It was lukewarm.  The coffee was hot but weak.   The worst thing was the feeling afterwards-knowing that what I'd just eaten really wasn't worth the calories.  A waste of a treat to myself.

The owner herself was quite friendly and works very hard-no wonder she's so slim.

But, average and lukewarm food, mixed up instructions and then overcharged?  I think my diet will survive the temptation of Karine's.

There are things I love about Winners-finding bargains is one of my greatest pleasures.  In fact, I think that thrill would still remain with me if I won Lotto Max.  Or, should I say WHEN I win Lotto Max.  Apparently all you need to do is dream hard enough-according to Oprah's guests anyway.

This is a reasonably large Winners.  Unfortunately this doesn't necessariiy equate with a good one.  Cosmetics are reasonable, as are shoes.  I like their homewares section.  I have my eye on a lamp for my bedroom and there are always little bits and pieces to tempt there.  

There are racks and racks of clothes as far as the eye can see.  It's amazing how much stock they have and how little of it is wearable.  You really do need to be motivated to search through it all to find something decent.  I'm just too lazy so walk through only to give up after 5 minutes.  

There are sometimes some good finds like headphones, sweets and trinkets on the stands near the cash registers.  This is good considering the lines are often absolutely horrendous-the distraction is needed.  I feel my patience ebb away as the line slowly inches forward.  When you actually get to the top of the line, the checkout experience is mixed.  I've had some nice assistants but the guy today was terrible.  No eye contact, definitely no smile and he was basically just downright rude.  I don't expect my transactions to involve haiku or sonnets, but monosyllabic barking (bag? here!) definitely does not create my ideal retail experience.

In summary, I like it for the homewares and sometimes the cosmetics.  It's tolerable on a weekday evening when the lines are shorter.  Sometimes they're civil too...or even nice.  I'd definitely choose the one on Front St over this though.  I leave less grumpy!

Brought the parents on a 1 hour tour thanks to Groupon. $10 for a trip around the harbourfront-how could you go wrong?

I have to say that one of the most striking things about the experience was how very pleasant everybody was. They were so friendly and full of beaming smiles! I don't know how they stay so perky. Our tour was narrated by Captain Sarah while Captain Kevin drove. I don't know how she copes with giving the same tour every day, but I enjoyed her jokes and learned a few new things about Toronto. 

I was a bit disappointed that it was a shallow, covered boat...but I suppose that's more practical. They stop at Centre Island half way through and you can choose to hop off and get a later boat back if you like. We were visiting on a weekday in June though, so they were only sailing hourly, with island pickups on the half hour.

The big test was what the parents thought of it and they were happy. Even my dad who can usually find something wrong and can never hear anything thought it was good! 

Downside for me was the infrequency of sailing in June. I wish it counted as their summer because half hourly departures would have been great.

My money management is woeful but I do love a bargain and Shoe Company gives me that happy glow!  It's an unassuming looking shop with pretty awful layout and merchandising but don't let that deter you....it has great potential for finds.  It also lacks that horrible smell of plastic you get in the really cheap shoe shops.  I managed to find the elusive cheap sandals that were comfy for walking and didn't look like I'd stolen them from a nun and was almost sucked into buying a pair of bargain Fit Flops.  It's not full of designer gear but has plenty of tempting bits and pieces.   This branch has a great running section at the back too.
